items.title: Live: PM flags day of mourning, minute's silence for Bondi victims
items.description: Anthony Albanese says he will confirm a "national day of mourning" for the Bondi attack in the new year, and has declared Sunday, December 21 as a day of reflection to honour the victims.

items.title: PM announces 'largest' gun buyback scheme since Howard era
items.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a national gun buyback scheme, days after a deadly terror attack on a Hanukkah celebration.

items.title: Men in dramatic Sydney arrest could soon be released, police say
items.description: Police now say the men may be released from custody, despite earlier claims the group held "extremist Islamic" views and may have been going to Bondi.

items.title: How the world reacted to the Bondi massacre
items.description: The shock waves from Sunday's deadly terror attack at Bondi Beach have reverberated around the world from the Middle East to Moscow and Manila.

items.title: Former police sergeant claims he warned of Bondi attack a decade ago
items.description: Steve Buttel says he told his bosses "it was only a matter of time" before there would be a terror attack on Bondi's Jewish community.

items.title: In pictures: Thousands turn out for 'victory over hate' paddle-out in Bondi
items.description: Thousands of locals packed the Bondi beachfront for an emotional paddle-out in honour of the victims of Sunday's terror attack.

items.title: Breaking: Brown University shooting suspect found dead, officials say
items.description: The suspect in last week's mass shooting at Brown University has been found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, officials say.

items.title: Live: ANZ to pay $250m penalty, ASX rises after Wall St rally
items.description: The Federal Court has increased penalties to be paid by ANZ to $250 million, while the ASX rises after strong gains on Wall Street overnight. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

items.title: Live: Labuschagne departs as England shows fight in Adelaide
items.description: Australia's batters look to build an imposing second-innings lead after Ben Stokes and Jofra Archer notch half-centuries to keep England in the game on day three in Adelaide.

items.title: More photos released on eve of Epstein files deadline
items.description: US Democrats continue their drip-feed of material from sex predator Jeffrey Epstein’s estate, releasing more photos on the eve of a deadline for the full publication of the Epstein files.

items.title: Dream life in Australia sold by influencers doesn't match reality
items.description: Influencers push a false promise of easy money and a better life in Australia with a Work and Holiday Visa, inspiring young Indonesians to take extreme measures to chase an almost unrealisable dream.

items.title: Family cuts weekly mortgage payment to $330 with rural move
items.description: The Ballini family made the move to regional Queensland where they are are paying half the mortgage they were in the south-east, but that's rapidly changing.

items.title: Child abuse falsely detected in bakery's social media
items.description: The Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman says he's seen a rise in small businesses disputes with digital platforms.

items.title: 'Better than anything Russia has got': Australian tanks arrive in Ukraine
items.description: The ABC is granted exclusive access to the ADF operation to transport M1A1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine, via Poland, which included an ocean voyage of more than 50 days.

items.title: Trump's hand-picked board renames arts centre as Trump Kennedy Center
items.description: The venue, named after former US president John F Kennedy, is to be renamed the Trump Kennedy Center after a vote by its board — which Mr Trump himself hand-picked this year.

items.title: Victorian premier's husband caught drink driving
items.description: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan has apologised after her husband was caught drink driving, saying the incident left her "disappointed and embarrassed".

items.title: 'Gladiator goes to sea': Russell Crowe on Master and Commander
items.description: Master and Commander flopped in 2003 but is now hailed as a masterpiece. Discover why this epic is earning renewed respect.

items.title: Life on a remote cattle station where 'people leave a little bit better'
items.description: The idea of life out on the edge of the desert has pulled in young people from across the country and overseas.

items.title: Expert disagrees with political argument against minimum prices for alcohol
items.description: A major study into alcohol policy in the NT has recommended tightening bottle shop trading hours, raising the minimum price of alcohol and reforming the approach to individual liquor bans in the territory.

items.title: Practice conditions put on neurosurgeon after behaviour complaints
items.description: Doctor Greg Malham, who was terminated from a Melbourne private hospital following an ABC investigation into his behaviour, will have to undertake mentoring sessions to continue practising.

items.title: Regional Victorian found not guilty of murder walks free despite jail cell admission
items.description: Jodie Hill wept as a Supreme Court jury found her not guilty of murder and manslaughter, follow a week of deliberations.

items.title: Man charged with murder of his 88-year-old mother refuses lawyer
items.description: Police say Thomas Andrew Tapley was his mother's carer and it is a tragic set of circumstances for the family.

items.title: This robot is designed to do your chores, but would you trust it?
items.description: Humanoid robots may be part of our future, but human psychology and the uncanny valley may stand between them and world domination.

items.title: Prince William and Princess Catherine release 2025 Christmas card
items.description: The Prince and Princess of Wales have released a new family portrait to coincide with their annual Christmas card.

items.title: Everything you need to know about the Jake Paul and Anthony Joshua fight
items.description: Jake Paul vs Anthony Joshua is not the first sham fight, neither will it be the last. But there is a real risk that, one way or another, it will have a lasting impact. Here's everything you need to know about the contest.
